### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max)
{}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max)
{}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max)
{}

   |

   | ^

   |             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{

    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&

```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable

```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max)
{}

        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max)
{}
``` using System;

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&

```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}
``` package org.apache.camel.quarkus.component.saxon.it;

   |
49 | {}
   | ^

   |
48 |     ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
   |             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}

Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.

Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max)
{}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)

SCORE
1.0
['lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)\n', 'lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)\n', 'lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)\n', 'lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)\n', 'lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)\n']

{

    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&

```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)

### (4) Predicate for Contains

predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}

{

    else
        match t

{

    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))

lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}

    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true

Dafny program verifier finished with 4 verified, 1 error

SCORE
-1.0
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}
``` package org.apache.flink.streaming.connectors.redis.common.config;

ex.dfy(49,0): Error: a postcondition could not be proved on this return path
   |
49 | {}
   | ^

ex.dfy(48,12): Related location: this is the postcondition that could not be proved
   |
48 |     ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
   |             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

    | Empty

    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}

### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}

    else

predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true

    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}
``` package com.github.j5ik2o.akka.persistence.dynamodb.journal

   |             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
datatype Tree =
    | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)
    | Empty
```

### (2) Predicate for Binary Search Tree
```dafny
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => true
    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&
                          IsBST(l, min, v) &&
                          IsBST(r, v, max)
}
```

### (3) Insert function
```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}
```

### (4) Predicate for Contains
```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}

    | Empty

predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
    match t

    case Node(l, v, r) => v > min && v < max &&

```dafny
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
    if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
    else
        match t
        case Node(l, w, r) =>
            if v < w then Node(Insert(l, v), w, r)
            else if v > w then Node(l, w, Insert(r, v))
            else t
        case Empty => t // unreachable
}

```dafny
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
    match t
    case Empty => false
    case Node(l, w, r) =>
        (v == w) ||
        (v < w && Contains(l, v)) ||
        (v > w && Contains(r, v))
}
```

### (5) Lemma for Insert
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Preserves_Contains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
    requires Contains(t, w) == true
    ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == true
{}
```

### (6) Lemma for BST property
```dafny
lemma {:induction} Insert_Maintains_BST(t: Tree, v: nat, min: nat, max: nat)
    requires IsBST(t, min, max) == true && min <= v && v <= max
    ensures IsBST(Insert(t, v), min, max) == true
{}

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny

  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
function IsBST(tree: Tree, min: nat, max: nat): bool

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
function IsBST(tree: Tree, min: nat, max: nat): bool
{
  match tree
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= min && value <= max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&
    IsBST(right, value + 1, max)

   |
14 |     IsBST(right, value + 1, max)
   |                                 ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.

Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
function IsBST(tree: Tree, min: nat, max: nat): bool
{
  match tree
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, value, right) =>
    value >= min && value <= max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&
    IsBST(right, value + 1, max)
}

ex.dfy(13,27): Error: value does not satisfy the subset constraints of 'nat'

   |                            ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat) 
  reads t 
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, value, right) => 
    value >= min && value <= max &&
    IsBST(left, min, value - 1) &&
    IsBST(right, value + 1, max)

   |
15 |     IsBST(right, value + 1, max)
   |                                 ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat) 
  reads t
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(l, v, r) =>
    l == Empty || IsBST(l, min, v)
    && v <= max
    && r == Empty || IsBST(r, v, max)

   |
14 |     && v <= max
   |     ^^

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate to check if a tree is a BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat) 
  reads t
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(l, v, r) =>
    l == Empty || IsBST(l, min, v)
    && v <= max
    && r == Empty || IsBST(r, v, max)
}

   |
14 |     && v <= max
   |     ^^

   |
15 |     && r == Empty || IsBST(r, v, max)
   |     ^^

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else

   |

   |       ^

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t

   |

   |          ^

  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{

  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains

{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element

SCORE
1.0

```dafny

datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{

  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains

{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains

{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContainment
{
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)

   |

   | ^

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContainment
{
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
  // Proof: by structural induction on t

   |
42 | {
   | ^

  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST

{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))

{

  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t

// (4) Define a predicate for contains

{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment

{
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
  // Proof: By structural induction on t

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContainment
{
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), v)
  // proof here

   |
42 | {
   | ^

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == (v == w || Contains(t, w))

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == (v == w || Contains(t, w))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t.

   |
44 |   // Proof by structural induction on t.
   |                                         ^

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == (v == w || Contains(t, w))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t.
  if t == Empty then
    assert Contains(Node(Empty, v, Empty), w) == Contains(Empty, w) == false;

```dafny

datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

{

  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t

{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == (v == w || Contains(t, w))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t.
  if t == Empty then
    assert Contains(Node(Empty, v, Empty), w) == Contains(Empty, w) == false;
    assert v != w;

  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == (v == w || Contains(t, w))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on t.
  if t == Empty then
    assert Contains(Node(Empty, v, Empty), w) == Contains(Empty, w) == false;
    assert Contains(Empty, v) == false;

   |
45 |   if t == Empty then
   |                 ^

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.

    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)

      else t
}

{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == (v == w || Contains(t, w))
{
  // base cases
  if t == Empty {
    assert Contains(Node(Empty, v, Empty), w) == (v == w);

   |
46 |     assert Contains(Node(Empty, v, Empty), w) == (v == w);
   |                                                           ^

    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))

{

  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>

      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))

  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == Contains(t, w) || w == v

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment

    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains

{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == Contains(t, w) || w == v
{

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == Contains(t, w) || w == v
{
  // proof by structural induction on t
  if t == Empty
  {

   |

   |    ^

    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&

{

  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true

  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == Contains(t, w) || w == v

{

  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>

      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t

  case Empty => false

    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true

lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == Contains(t, w) || w == v
{
  // proof by structural induction on t
  if t == Empty
  {
  }
  else
  {
    var left := t.left;
    var right := t.right;

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).
Then (3) write a function that inserts an element into a binary search tree while preserving the BST property.
Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.
### Hint: For each proof, do not use assertions. Just analyze the structure based on the insert function, and recursively call the lemma to match the recursive calls in the function.
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: do not have `requires` nor `ensures` clauses in the insert function. The lemmas will be proved after the definition; in those lemmas, have `requires` and `ensures` clauses.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function
function Insert(t: Tree, v: nat): Tree
{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains
predicate Contains(t: Tree, v: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == Contains(t, w) || w == v
{
  // proof by structural induction on t
  if t == Empty
  {
  }
  else
  {
    var left := t.left;
    var value := t.value;

   |
51 |     var value := t.value;
   |                          ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
}

// (5) Define a lemma for insert preserving containment
lemma InsertPreservesContains(t: Tree, v: nat, w: nat)
  ensures Contains(Insert(t, v), w) == Contains(t, w) || w == v
{
  // proof by structural induction on t
  if t == Empty
  {
  }
  else
  {
    var left := t.left;
    var right := t.right;
    var w := t.value;
    InsertPreservesContains(left, v, w);
    InsertPreservesContains(right, v, w);
  }
}

### Spec: In Dafny, (1) write an ADT for a tree of natural numbers.
Then (2) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree is a binary search tree (BST).

Then (4) write a predicate that checks whether a given tree contains a given element.
Then (5) write a lemma about the insert function that ensures that the tree resulting from inserting an element contains that element (without requiring nor ensuring the BST property).
Then (6) write another lemma about the insert function that checks the BST property continues to hold after insertion. This lemma should take bounds on the BST, and require that the element to be inserted is within those bounds.

```dafny
// (1) Define the ADT for a tree of natural numbers
datatype Tree =
  | Empty
  | Node(left: Tree, value: nat, right: Tree)

// (2) Define a predicate for BST
predicate IsBST(t: Tree, min: nat, max: nat)
{
  match t
  case Empty => true
  case Node(left, v, right) =>
    v >= min && v <= max &&
    (left == Empty || (v > min && IsBST(left, min, v - 1))) &&
    (right == Empty || (v < max && IsBST(right, v + 1, max)))
}

// (3) Define the insert function

{
  if t == Empty then Node(Empty, v, Empty)
  else
    match t
    case Node(left, w, right) =>
      if v < w then Node(Insert(left, v), w, right)
      else if v > w then Node(left, w, Insert(right, v))
      else t
}

// (4) Define a predicate for contains

{
  match t
  case Empty => false
  case Node(left, w, right) =>
    if v < w then Contains(left, v)
    else if v > w then Contains(right, v)
    else true
